snippet.title: Cubs hit 3 HRs, break loose to beat Reds 8-4
snippet.description: Rick Renteria prefers positive reinforcement, usually taking the approach of building up his players.

snippet.title: Kansas speech by Michelle Obama draws complaints
snippet.description: If expanding the guest list to include Michelle Obama at graduation for high school students in the Kansas capital city means fewer seats for friends and family, some students and their parents would prefer the first lady not attend.

snippet.title: Jet Lag Nation: In Washington, the zombies walk among us
snippet.description: With international travel on the rise, more people in D.C. are on a sleep cycle split between continents.

snippet.title: Barry Ritholtz column: What's gone up won't always come down
snippet.description: You might think that after last year's strong gains, the markets might be due for a breather, but . . .

snippet.title: Who are the one-third of Americans pessimistic about tech?
snippet.description: Why aren't they as excited about our science fiction future?

snippet.title: Big data: A double-edged sword
snippet.description: New information will improve our health and prevent crimes, but uncover skeletons and hurt privacy.

snippet.title: Analysis: Hoping legislative defeats boost turnout
snippet.description: Flip sides of the same campaign-season coin, the Republican drive in Congress to repeal the nation's health care law and the Democratic call to close the pay gap for women have much in common.

snippet.title: Column: no April, May or June Madness in NBA
snippet.description: If the playoff-bound Atlanta Hawks were in any other sport, they might have a glimmer of hope for winning a championship.

snippet.title: Astros fall behind early, lose to A's 11-3
snippet.description: Bo Porter's team had already fallen behind big when he lost his temper.

snippet.title: Mixed feelings for Garcia Marquez in hometown
snippet.description: Gabriel Garcia Marquez and his homeland had a relationship as conflicted as any in the Nobel laureate's twisting and impassioned novels.
